subsubsection.title: Evaluate exponential functions
subsubsection.p: Powers come before products in the order of operations, so to evaluate an exponential function f(x)=ab^x we evaluate b^x before multiplying by a.

solution.p:
Follow the order of operations: compute powers before products.
f(2)=8 \cdot 4^2 = 8\cdot 16 = 128
f(-2)=8 \cdot 4^{-2} = 8\cdot \dfrac{1}{16} = \dfrac{1}{2}
f\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)=8 \cdot 4^{1/2} = 8\cdot 2 = 16
f\left(-\frac{1}{2}\right)=8 \cdot 4^{-1/2} = 8\cdot \dfrac{1}{2} = 4

introduction.p: If we can write both sides of an equation as powers with the same base, we can equate the exponents.

li.p: We can write both sides with base 3. ~~ 81 = 3^4,~~~\text{so} ~~x=4.
We can write both sides with base 5. ~~125 = 5^3,~~~ \text{so}~~~5^{-3} = \dfrac{1}{125},~~~ \text{and} ~~x=-3.

statement.p:
By using trial and error, estimate the value of the exponent to the nearest tenth.
2^x=15
3^x=65
10^x=0.03
0.5^x = 0.20

ol.li: 2^4=16~, so we try a slightly smaller exponent and find that 2^{3.9} = 14.9285~, so x \approx 3.9.
65 is between 3^3=27 and 3^4=81, so x must be between 3 and 4. By trying exponents 3.1, 3.2, 3.3, and so on, we find that 3^{3.8}=65.022, so x \approx 3.8.
10^{-1}=0.1 and 10^{-2}=0.01, so -2 \lt x \lt -1. By trying exponents between -2 and -1, we find that 10^{-1.5} = 0.0316, so x \approx -1.5.
0.5^2 = 0.25, and as we increase the exponent on 0.5, the result will be smaller. By trial and error we find that 0.5^{2.3} = 0.2031, so x \approx 2.3.

subsubsection.title: Solve equations graphically
subsubsection.p: We first solve equations graphically in Section 1.2, so you might want to review that subsection.

statement.p: Here is a graph of f(x)=x^2+2x-16. Use the graph to solve the equation x^2+2x-16=8. Show your work on the graph.

solution.p: To solve the equation, we want to find x-values that produce a function value of 8. The vertical coordinate of each point on the graph is given by the function value, f(x). So we look for points on the graph with vertical coordinate f(x)=8.

There are two such points, (-6,8) and (4,8). Those points tell us that f(-6)=8 and f(4)=8. Thus, the x-coordinates of the points, namely -6 and 4, are the solutions. To check algebraically, we can verify that f(-6)=8 and f(4)=8: f(\alert{-6}) \amp = (\alert{-6})^2+2(\alert{-6})-16 = 36-12-16 = 8 f(\alert{4})\amp = \alert{4}^2+2(\alert{4})-16 = 16+8-16 = 8

statement.p: Here is a graph of G(x)=\dfrac{20}{(x-3)^2}. Use the graph to solve the equation \dfrac{20}{(x-3)^2} = 5. Show your work on the graph.

sidebyside.p: We find any points on the graph with vertical coordinate G(x)=5. There are two points, (1,5) and (5,5.) The x-coordinates of those points, namely 1 and 5, are the solutions.
